Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story: I sat on the edge of the bed, blueprints spread across my lap, lines and measurements blurring together. My phone buzzed again—a message from her, just a simple “Can you come over?” I knew she needed me. Her father’s passing had left her adrift, and I was supposed to be her anchor, the one who listened, who held her when the tears came. But tomorrow, I had to start the biggest project of my career. The plans were complicated, and I hadn’t even finished reading through the technical documents. If I messed up, it would cost the company and my reputation. My heart twisted as I stared at the phone, guilt gnawing at me. I wanted to be there for her, to hold her hand and let her know she wasn’t alone. But the weight of the blueprints pressed down on me, reminding me of everything at stake. I closed my eyes, torn between the person I loved and the work I’d built my life around, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
